{{for|the Portuguese Navy frigate NRP ''Diogo Cão'' (F 333)|USS Formoe (DE-509)}} {{Infobox person | name = Diogo Cão | image = Diogo Cão.jpg | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = ca. 1452 | birth_place = [[Vila Real, Portugal|Vila Real]], [[Kingdom of Portugal]] | death_date = ca. 1486 | death_place = | nationality = [[Portuguese People|Portuguese]] | citizenship = | occupation = Navigator and explorer | known_for = First European to explore the Congo River and the west coast of Africa. | signature = }} '''Diogo Cão''' ({{IPA-pt|diˈoɣu ˈkɐ̃w̃}}), anglicised as '''Diogo Cam''' and also known as '''Diego Cam''',<ref>{{citation |contribution=[[s:Encyclopædia Britannica, Ninth Edition/Angola|Angola]] |title=''[[s:Encyclopædia Britannica, Ninth Edition|''Encyclopædia Britannica'', 9th ed.]], [[s:Encyclopædia Britannica, Ninth Edition/Volume II|Vol. II]]'' |editor-last=Baynes |editor-first=Thomas Spencer |display-editors=0 |publisher=Charles Scribner's Sons |location=New York |date=1878 |ref={{harvid|EB|1878}} |p=45 }}.</ref> was a [[Portugal|Portuguese]] [[exploration|explorer]] and one of the most notable [[navigators]] of the [[Age of Discovery]]. He made two voyages sailing along the west coast of [[Africa]] in the 1480s, exploring the [[Congo River]] and the coasts of the present-day [[Angola]] and [[Namibia]].{{sfn|Beazley|1911{{full citation needed|date=May 2019}}}}
==Early life and family== Cão was born in [[Vila Real, Portugal|Vila Real]] (some say in [[Évora]]), in the middle of the 15th century, the illegitimate son of Álvaro Fernandes or Gonçalves Cão, [[fidalgo]] of the [[Royal Household]], himself the illegitimate son of Gonçalo Cão. He married and had four children: Pedro Cão, Manuel Cão, André Afonso Cão, and Isabel Cão.
His Christian name was Jacobus. "Cão" was a nickname meaning "dog", which means his nickname translated to "Diego the dog".<ref name="1482 congo">[http://www.crossingtheoceansea.com/OceanSeaPages/OS-51-DiogoCaoCongo.html 1482 – Diogo Cão Reaches the Congo], ''Crossingtheoceansea.com'' (accessed on 20 May 2019){{self-published source|date=February 2020}}</ref>{{self-published inline|date=February 2020}}
==Explorer== [[File:Portuguese discoveries diogo cao.jpg|thumb|190px|Diogo Cão]] He was the first European known to sight and enter the [[Congo River]] and to explore the West African coast between Cape St. Catherine in [[Gabon]] and [[Cape Cross]], almost from the [[equator]] to [[Walvis Bay]] in Namibia.<ref name=EB1911>{{EB1911|inline=1|wstitle=Cam (Cão), Diogo|last=Beazley |first=Charles Raymond |authorlink=Raymond Beazley| volume=5 |page=79}}</ref>
===First voyage=== [[Image:Caopillar.JPG|thumb|130px|The [[padrão]] bearing the arms of Portugal erected by Cão at Cape St. Mary]] When King [[John II of Portugal]] restarted the work of [[Henry the Navigator]], he sent out Cão (probably around midsummer 1482) to explore the African coast south of the [[equator]]. Diogo Cão filled his ship with stone pillars surmounted by the cross of the Order of Christ and engraved with the Portuguese royal arms ([[padrão]]s), with the plan to erect one in every new place he would discover.<ref name="1482 congo"/>
On his way, he stopped in the newly-built [[Elmina Castle]] to stock up.<ref name="1482 congo"/>
He discovered the mouth and [[estuary]] of the Congo, probably in August 1482 and marked it with a padrão, or stone pillar erected on Shark Point, attesting to the sovereignty of [[Portugal]]. This padrão still stands to this day, albeit in ruins.
He also ascended the great river for a short distance, and commenced modest commerce with the natives of the [[Kingdom of Kongo|Bakongo]] kingdom. He was told that their King lived farther upriver. He sent 4 men to meet the King, kept four natives to serve as ambassadors of Kongo in Portugal, and sailed back down the river to the Atlantic.<ref name="1482 congo"/> Cão then coasted down along the present [[Angola]] (Portuguese West Africa), and erected a second padrão, probably marking the termination of this voyage, at Cape Saint Mary (the Monte Negro of these first visitors).<ref name="EB1911"/>
The first padrão erected at the mouth of the Congo River, the S. Jorge, has been taken by an English ship that sunk, according to indigenous rumors (the base is still there). The second one, the St. Agostinho, still stands today, but misses its cross on top.{{cn|date=February 2020}} [[File:Armas Diogo Cão.jpg|thumb|left|100px|Diogo Cão's Coat of Arms]] He returned to Lisbon by 8 April 1484 (on his return he discovered the Island of [[Annobón]]), where John II ennobled him, promoting him from esquire to a [[knight]] of his [[Court (royal) | household]], and granted him an annuity (10000 reais) and a coat of arms where two padrões are represented. The King also asked him to sail back to Kongo to repatriate the 4 men he left behind.<ref name="EB1911"/><ref name="1482 congo"/>
===Second voyage=== [[Image:Matadi, Congo, pedra de Ielala, Diogo Cão.jpg|thumb|300px|Stone of Ielala, with the inscriptions of Diogo Cão]] That Cão, on his second voyage of 1484–1486, was accompanied by [[Martin Behaim]] (as alleged on the latter's Nuremberg globe of 1492) is very doubtful. But it is known that the explorer revisited the Congo and erected two more padrãos on land beyond his previous voyage. The first was at Cabo Negro, Angola, the second at [[Cape Cross]]. The Cape Cross pillar probably marked the end of his progress southward, some 1,400 kilometers.<ref name="EB1911"/> Diogo Cão also embarked the 4 indigenous ambassadors, that he had promised not to keep for more than fifteen moons.{{cn|date=February 2020}}
Cão ascended the [[Congo River|Kongo River]] (which he thought led towards the realm of [[Prester John]]), up to the neighborhood of the site of [[Matadi]]. There, in October or November 1485, near the falls of [[Yellala Falls|Ielala]], he left an inscription engraved on the stone which testifies of its passage and that of his men: ''Aqui chegaram os navios do esclarecido rei D.João II de Portugal - Diogo Cão, Pero Anes, Pero da Costa.'' ("Here reached the ships of the enlightened king [[John II of Portugal]] – Diogo Cão, Pero Anes, Pero da Costa").
According to one authority (a legend on the 1489 map of [[Henricus Martellus Germanus]]), Cão died off [[Cape Cross]]; but [[João de Barros]] and others wrote of his return to the Kongo, and subsequent taking of a native envoy to Portugal. A report by a board of astronomers and pilots presented at a 1525 conference in Badajo clearly stated that his death happened near Serra Parda. A coast map by [[Henricus Martellus Germanus]] published in 1489 indicated the location of a padrão erected by Diogo Cão in Ponta dos Farilhões nearby Serra Parda, with the legend "et hic moritur" ("and here he died"). The Venetian cartographer [[Pietro Coppo]] corroborated this location of death in 1520.{{cn|date=February 2020}}
The four pillars set up by Cão on his two voyages have all been discovered still on their original site, and the inscriptions on two of them from Cape Santa Maria and Cape Cross, dated 1482 and 1485 respectively, are still to be read and have been printed. The Cape Cross padrão is now at [[Berlin]] (replaced on the spot by a granite facsimile); those from the Kongo estuary and the more southerly Cape Santa Maria and Cabo Negro are in the Museum of the Lisbon Geographical Society.<ref name="EB1911"/>
==Tributes post-mortem== In [[Vila Real]], the plaza Diogo Cão was named after him. In the center of the plaza stands a bronze statue of him supported by a square granite pedestal base.<ref>[https://www.minube.net/place/monument-to-diogo-cao--a150562 Monument to Diogo Cão], ''Minube.net'' (accessed on 20 May 2019)</ref>
In 1999, André Roubertou from the French Hydrographic Office (SHOM) named an undersea hole located off the southern coast of Portugal ([[Gulf of Cádiz]]) the Diogo Cão Hole.<ref>[http://www.marineregions.org/gazetteer.php?p=details&id=4832 Marine Gazetteer Placedetails], ''Marineregions.org'' (accessed on 20 May 2019)</ref>
In 2018, a [[trailing suction hopper dredger|hopper dredger]] called the Diogo Cao and immatriculated in Luxembourg was launched afloat.<ref>[https://www.vesselfinder.com/vessels/DIOGO-CAO-IMO-9823481-MMSI-253617000 DIOGO CAO - HOPPER DREDGER], ''Vesselfinder.com'' (accessed on 20 May 2019)</ref>
==In literature==
Diogo Cão is the subject of ''Padrão'', one of the best-known poems in [[Fernando Pessoa]]'s book ''Mensagem'', the only one published during the author's lifetime. He also figures strongly in the 1996 novel ''Lord of the Kongo'' by Peter Forbath.
